option_1.condition: You can see and count every symbol distinctly

option_2.condition: You CANNOT count exactly for ANY reason
option_2.example: CANNOT COUNT - symbols overlap at grid B2, centers not distinguishable

business_impact: Wrong count = budget errors (thousands of dollars)
why_this_matters.the_truth: A wrong number presented confidently is WORSE than admitting you cannot count

the_protocol.step_2: Can you see its COMPLETE boundary distinctly? YES/NO
the_protocol.step_3: Can you see its CENTER distinctly? YES/NO
the_protocol.step_4: Is it separated from other symbols? YES/NO
the_protocol.step_5a: If ALL YES → Count it, add to total
the_protocol.step_5b: If ANY NO → Do NOT count, FLAG the area

when_to_stop_and_flag: Symbols overlap and you cannot distinguish individuals
Resolution is too low to see boundaries
Part of symbol is cut off at edge
Symbol is obscured by text or other elements
You are uncertain for ANY reason

the_mindset.wrong: I think there are about 5, so I'll say 5
the_mindset.wrong_2: It could be 4 or 6, so I'll say 5 as middle ground
the_mindset.wrong_3: I see 4 clearly but there might be 1-2 more hidden, so 4-6
the_mindset.correct: I see 4 symbols with certainty. Area X has overlapping elements I CANNOT COUNT. Total certain: 4. Flagged for review: Area X.

flagged_areas: list areas that CANNOT BE COUNTED with reason
A1 cluster: CANNOT COUNT - 3+ symbols overlap, centers not visible
B1 dense area: CANNOT COUNT - resolution insufficient
example_incomplete.status: INCOMPLETE - human review required for flagged areas

final_rule: If you cannot state a single integer with 100% certainty, you MUST say CANNOT COUNT. There is no middle ground.
